`<!-- hide -->
# The Postcard
<!-- endhide -->

Who doesn't like postcards? This is one of your first exercises (if not the first), and it's fun and relatively easy :)

Let's create a postcard with HTML5 and CSS3, and then you can share it with your mom or your other half; they will be proud! :)

<onlyfor saas="false" withBanner="false">
  
## üå±  How to start this project?

1. Make sure you have a Github account at:  https://github.com
2. We recommend opening this repository using a provisioning tool like [Codespaces](https://4geeks.com/lesson/what-is-github-codespaces) (recommended) or [Gitpod](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-use-gitpod). Alternatively, you can clone it on your local computer using the `git clone` command. 

This is the repository you need to open or clone:

```text
https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard
```

**üëâ Please follow these steps on** [how to start a coding project](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-start-a-project). IMPORTANT --> this repo isn't a template. 


3. The exercises will start and show the instructions automatically, but if you encounter any issues, you can try running them manually by typing in your command line the following:

```bash
$ learnpack start
```

</onlyfor>

## Instructions

Create the HTML and CSS3 needed to replicate [this exact same picture](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png).

![postcard preview](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png)

> ‚úã Here is the url for the 4Geeks logo: [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true)

## Create by drawing your strategy

![Postcard Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/raw/main/.learn/assets/strategy.gif?raw=true)

## You can add different fonts by using free [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/)

1. Click on the font you like.

2. Click get font.

3. Click on Embed code.

4. Add the link tags to your html file.


## What to do if you are stuck?

There is a video about this exercise, watch it if you are lost. But don't copy everything, try to code some of your own.

## Fundamentals
This exercise covers the following fundamentals:
1. Basic structure for every HTML5 website.  
2. The *Link* tag to import CSS3 Rules.  
3. Using google fonts.  
3. Using the different selectors available in CSS3.  
4. Working with containers or boxes: border, padding, and margins.  
5. Overflow.  
6. Using a simple form.  

This and many other exercises are built by students as part of the 4Geeks Academy [Coding Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamp) by [Alejandro S√°nchez](https://twitter.com/alesanchezr) and many other contributors. Find out more about our [Full Stack Developer Course](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/part-time-full-stack-developer), and  [Data Science Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/datascience-machine-learning).


`

1. **Project Structure**: The root directory is typically the main folder that contains all your project files and subfolders. It usually includes files like `index.html`, `README.md`, and any other main files related to your project.

2. **File Explorer**: If you're using a code editor or an integrated development environment (IDE), look at the file explorer panel. The top-level folder displayed there is usually your root directory.

3. **Command Line**: If you're using a command line interface, you can navigate to your project folder using commands like `cd` (change directory). Once you're in the project folder, you can use the command `pwd` (print working directory) on Unix-based systems or `cd` without arguments on Windows to see the current directory path.

`<!-- hide -->
# The Postcard
<!-- endhide -->

Who doesn't like postcards? This is one of your first exercises (if not the first), and it's fun and relatively easy :)

Let's create a postcard with HTML5 and CSS3, and then you can share it with your mom or your other half; they will be proud! :)

<onlyfor saas="false" withBanner="false">
  
## üå±  How to start this project?

1. Make sure you have a Github account at:  https://github.com
2. We recommend opening this repository using a provisioning tool like [Codespaces](https://4geeks.com/lesson/what-is-github-codespaces) (recommended) or [Gitpod](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-use-gitpod). Alternatively, you can clone it on your local computer using the `git clone` command. 

This is the repository you need to open or clone:

```text
https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard
```

**üëâ Please follow these steps on** [how to start a coding project](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-start-a-project). IMPORTANT --> this repo isn't a template. 


3. The exercises will start and show the instructions automatically, but if you encounter any issues, you can try running them manually by typing in your command line the following:

```bash
$ learnpack start
```

</onlyfor>

## Instructions

Create the HTML and CSS3 needed to replicate [this exact same picture](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png).

![postcard preview](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png)

> ‚úã Here is the url for the 4Geeks logo: [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true)

## Create by drawing your strategy

![Postcard Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/raw/main/.learn/assets/strategy.gif?raw=true)

## You can add different fonts by using free [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/)

1. Click on the font you like.

2. Click get font.

3. Click on Embed code.

4. Add the link tags to your html file.


## What to do if you are stuck?

There is a video about this exercise, watch it if you are lost. But don't copy everything, try to code some of your own.

## Fundamentals
This exercise covers the following fundamentals:
1. Basic structure for every HTML5 website.  
2. The *Link* tag to import CSS3 Rules.  
3. Using google fonts.  
3. Using the different selectors available in CSS3.  
4. Working with containers or boxes: border, padding, and margins.  
5. Overflow.  
6. Using a simple form.  

This and many other exercises are built by students as part of the 4Geeks Academy [Coding Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamp) by [Alejandro S√°nchez](https://twitter.com/alesanchezr) and many other contributors. Find out more about our [Full Stack Developer Course](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/part-time-full-stack-developer), and  [Data Science Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/datascience-machine-learning).


`

const { fromFile, fromHTML } = require("../../utils/dom");

    const indexExists = fs.existsSync(`./index.html`);
    expect(indexExists).toBe(true);
})

test("Make sure you created the styles.css file", function(){
    const indexExists = fs.existsSync(`./styles.css`);
    expect(indexExists).toBe(true);
})

test("Make sure your index.html contains the <link> tag", function(){
    const content = fs.readFileSync("./index.html", 'utf8')
    document.documentElement.innerHTML = content.toString();
    const linkTag = _document.querySelector("link")
    expect(linkTag).not.toBe(null);
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-header as child of .postcard", function(){
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-header')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-body as child of .postcard", function(){
    dom = fromFile();
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-body')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-footer as child of .postcard", function(){
    dom = fromFile();
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-footer')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})
`

`<!-- hide -->
# The Postcard
<!-- endhide -->

Who doesn't like postcards? This is one of your first exercises (if not the first), and it's fun and relatively easy :)

Let's create a postcard with HTML5 and CSS3, and then you can share it with your mom or your other half; they will be proud! :)

<onlyfor saas="false" withBanner="false">
  
## üå±  How to start this project?

1. Make sure you have a Github account at:  https://github.com
2. We recommend opening this repository using a provisioning tool like [Codespaces](https://4geeks.com/lesson/what-is-github-codespaces) (recommended) or [Gitpod](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-use-gitpod). Alternatively, you can clone it on your local computer using the `git clone` command. 

This is the repository you need to open or clone:

```text
https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard
```

**üëâ Please follow these steps on** [how to start a coding project](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-start-a-project). IMPORTANT --> this repo isn't a template. 


3. The exercises will start and show the instructions automatically, but if you encounter any issues, you can try running them manually by typing in your command line the following:

```bash
$ learnpack start
```

</onlyfor>

## Instructions

Create the HTML and CSS3 needed to replicate [this exact same picture](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png).

![postcard preview](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png)

> ‚úã Here is the url for the 4Geeks logo: [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true)

## Create by drawing your strategy

![Postcard Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/raw/main/.learn/assets/strategy.gif?raw=true)

## You can add different fonts by using free [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/)

1. Click on the font you like.

2. Click get font.

3. Click on Embed code.

4. Add the link tags to your html file.


## What to do if you are stuck?

There is a video about this exercise, watch it if you are lost. But don't copy everything, try to code some of your own.

## Fundamentals
This exercise covers the following fundamentals:
1. Basic structure for every HTML5 website.  
2. The *Link* tag to import CSS3 Rules.  
3. Using google fonts.  
3. Using the different selectors available in CSS3.  
4. Working with containers or boxes: border, padding, and margins.  
5. Overflow.  
6. Using a simple form.  

This and many other exercises are built by students as part of the 4Geeks Academy [Coding Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamp) by [Alejandro S√°nchez](https://twitter.com/alesanchezr) and many other contributors. Find out more about our [Full Stack Developer Course](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/part-time-full-stack-developer), and  [Data Science Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/datascience-machine-learning).


`

const path = require("path");
const { fromFile, fromHTML } = require("../../utils/dom");
let dom = fromFile();

test("Make sure you have your index.html", function(){
    const indexExists = fs.existsSync(`./index.html`);
    expect(indexExists).toBe(true);
})

test("Make sure you created the styles.css file", function(){
    const indexExists = fs.existsSync(`./styles.css`);
    expect(indexExists).toBe(true);
})

test("Make sure your index.html contains the <link> tag", function(){
    const content = fs.readFileSync("./index.html", 'utf8')
    document.documentElement.innerHTML = content.toString();
    const linkTag = _document.querySelector("link")
    expect(linkTag).not.toBe(null);
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-header as child of .postcard", function(){
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-header')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-body as child of .postcard", function(){
    dom = fromFile();
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-body')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})

test("Create a div with class postcard-footer as child of .postcard", function(){
    dom = fromFile();
    const e=dom.querySelector('.postcard').inside().querySelector('.postcard-footer')
    expect(e).toBeTruthy();
})
`

`<!-- hide -->
# The Postcard
<!-- endhide -->

Who doesn't like postcards? This is one of your first exercises (if not the first), and it's fun and relatively easy :)

Let's create a postcard with HTML5 and CSS3, and then you can share it with your mom or your other half; they will be proud! :)

<onlyfor saas="false" withBanner="false">
  
## üå±  How to start this project?

1. Make sure you have a Github account at:  https://github.com
2. We recommend opening this repository using a provisioning tool like [Codespaces](https://4geeks.com/lesson/what-is-github-codespaces) (recommended) or [Gitpod](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-use-gitpod). Alternatively, you can clone it on your local computer using the `git clone` command. 

This is the repository you need to open or clone:

```text
https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard
```

**üëâ Please follow these steps on** [how to start a coding project](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-start-a-project). IMPORTANT --> this repo isn't a template. 


3. The exercises will start and show the instructions automatically, but if you encounter any issues, you can try running them manually by typing in your command line the following:

```bash
$ learnpack start
```

</onlyfor>

## Instructions

Create the HTML and CSS3 needed to replicate [this exact same picture](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png).

![postcard preview](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png)

> ‚úã Here is the url for the 4Geeks logo: [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true)

## Create by drawing your strategy

![Postcard Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/raw/main/.learn/assets/strategy.gif?raw=true)

## You can add different fonts by using free [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/)

1. Click on the font you like.

2. Click get font.

3. Click on Embed code.

4. Add the link tags to your html file.


## What to do if you are stuck?

There is a video about this exercise, watch it if you are lost. But don't copy everything, try to code some of your own.

## Fundamentals
This exercise covers the following fundamentals:
1. Basic structure for every HTML5 website.  
2. The *Link* tag to import CSS3 Rules.  
3. Using google fonts.  
3. Using the different selectors available in CSS3.  
4. Working with containers or boxes: border, padding, and margins.  
5. Overflow.  
6. Using a simple form.  

This and many other exercises are built by students as part of the 4Geeks Academy [Coding Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamp) by [Alejandro S√°nchez](https://twitter.com/alesanchezr) and many other contributors. Find out more about our [Full Stack Developer Course](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/part-time-full-stack-developer), and  [Data Science Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/datascience-machine-learning).


`
>

This is the current exercise instructions:
# `11.2` Header Styles

If you build your postcard and preview, you will come to the following conclusions:

1. The image needs to be on the right instead of below the title.

2. We need to make the image smaller.

To move the image to the right you can use the `display:flex` property. When you apply it to any `<div>`, all of its children will be arranged horizontally instead of vertically (by default).

![display flex vs block](../../assets/display-block-vs-flex.png?raw=true)

On the other hand, to make the image smaller we have to use the CSS properties: `width` and `height`.

## üìù Instructions:

1. Apply a `display:flex` property to the `.postcard-header`.

```css
.postcard-header {
	display: x;
}
```

2. Apply to the image a smaller `width` and `height`, to make it quite a bit smaller, maybe `50px x 50px`.

```css 
.postcard-header img {
	width: x;
	height: x;
}
```

3. Make the `<h1>` much wider to push the image to the right side of the postcard. Also remove the margins from the `<h1>`.

```css
.postcard-header h1 {
	width: x;
	margin: x;
}
```

`<!-- hide -->
# The Postcard
<!-- endhide -->

Who doesn't like postcards? This is one of your first exercises (if not the first), and it's fun and relatively easy :)

Let's create a postcard with HTML5 and CSS3, and then you can share it with your mom or your other half; they will be proud! :)

<onlyfor saas="false" withBanner="false">
  
## üå±  How to start this project?

1. Make sure you have a Github account at:  https://github.com
2. We recommend opening this repository using a provisioning tool like [Codespaces](https://4geeks.com/lesson/what-is-github-codespaces) (recommended) or [Gitpod](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-use-gitpod). Alternatively, you can clone it on your local computer using the `git clone` command. 

This is the repository you need to open or clone:

```text
https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard
```

**üëâ Please follow these steps on** [how to start a coding project](https://4geeks.com/lesson/how-to-start-a-project). IMPORTANT --> this repo isn't a template. 


3. The exercises will start and show the instructions automatically, but if you encounter any issues, you can try running them manually by typing in your command line the following:

```bash
$ learnpack start
```

</onlyfor>

## Instructions

Create the HTML and CSS3 needed to replicate [this exact same picture](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png).

![postcard preview](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/main/.learn/assets/preview.png)

> ‚úã Here is the url for the 4Geeks logo: [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/blob/main/.learn/assets/4geeks.png?raw=true)

## Create by drawing your strategy

![Postcard Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-postcard/raw/main/.learn/assets/strategy.gif?raw=true)

## You can add different fonts by using free [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/)

1. Click on the font you like.

2. Click get font.

3. Click on Embed code.

4. Add the link tags to your html file.


## What to do if you are stuck?

There is a video about this exercise, watch it if you are lost. But don't copy everything, try to code some of your own.

## Fundamentals
This exercise covers the following fundamentals:
1. Basic structure for every HTML5 website.  
2. The *Link* tag to import CSS3 Rules.  
3. Using google fonts.  
3. Using the different selectors available in CSS3.  
4. Working with containers or boxes: border, padding, and margins.  
5. Overflow.  
6. Using a simple form.  

This and many other exercises are built by students as part of the 4Geeks Academy [Coding Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamp) by [Alejandro S√°nchez](https://twitter.com/alesanchezr) and many other contributors. Find out more about our [Full Stack Developer Course](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/part-time-full-stack-developer), and  [Data Science Bootcamp](https://4geeksacademy.com/us/coding-bootcamps/datascience-machine-learning).


`

    dom = dom.withStylesheet();

    expect(dom).toBeTruthy();
})

test("The .postcard-header <div> must have a display:flex to allow its childs to display horizontally", function(){

        display: "flex",

This is the current exercise instructions:
# `11.2` Header Styles

If you build your postcard and preview, you will come to the following conclusions:

1. The image needs to be on the right instead of below the title.

2. We need to make the image smaller.

To move the image to the right you can use the `display:flex` property. When you apply it to any `<div>`, all of its children will be arranged horizontally instead of vertically (by default).

![display flex vs block](../../assets/display-block-vs-flex.png?raw=true)

On the other hand, to make the image smaller we have to use the CSS properties: `width` and `height`.

## üìù Instructions:

1. Apply a `display:flex` property to the `.postcard-header`.

```css
.postcard-header {
	display: x;
}
```

2. Apply to the image a smaller `width` and `height`, to make it quite a bit smaller, maybe `50px x 50px`.

```css 
.postcard-header img {
	width: x;
	height: x;
}
```

3. Make the `<h1>` much wider to push the image to the right side of the postcard. Also remove the margins from the `<h1>`.

```css
.postcard-header h1 {
	width: x;
	margin: x;
}
```

## Expected Result:

+ At the end your exercise should look similar to this one:

    ![Preview](../../assets/header-styles.png?raw=true)

>‚ö†Ô∏è Note: We are going to be a little bit more flexible with the tests, we want to leave you space to try things on your own. Please, compare your website preview with the expected image and keep trying!

>

To save your code, you typically follow these steps depending on the environment you are using:

1. **If you are using a code editor (like Visual Studio Code, Sublime Text, etc.):**
   - After making changes to your code, you can save the file by clicking on `File` in the menu and then selecting `Save`, or you can use the keyboard shortcut:
     - **Windows/Linux**: `Ctrl + S`
     - **Mac**: `Cmd + S`

2. **If you are using an online platform (like GitHub Codespaces or Gitpod):**
   - Most online editors automatically save your changes, but you can also look for a save button or use the same keyboard shortcuts mentioned above.

3. **If you are using Git for version control:**
   - After saving your changes in your code editor, you can commit your changes to your local repository. Here‚Äôs how:
     - Open your terminal or command line.
     - Navigate to your project directory.
     - Use the following commands:
       ```bash
       git add .
       git commit -m "Your commit message here"
       git push
       ```
   - This will save your changes to your local Git repository and push them to the remote repository on GitHub.

To determine the appropriate value for the `padding` property in your `.body-left` and `.body-right` classes, consider the design of the postcard you are trying to replicate. 

Padding is used to create space inside an element, between the element's content and its border. A common practice is to use values like `10px`, `15px`, or `20px`, depending on how much space you want.

For example, you could use:

```css
.body-left, .body-right {
    padding: 10px; /* This adds 10 pixels of padding on all sides */
}
```

You can adjust the value based on how it looks in your design. If you want different padding for each side, you can specify them individually like this:

```css
.body-left, .body-right {
    padding: 10px 15px; /* This adds 10 pixels of padding on the top and bottom, and 15 pixels on the left and right */
}
```

Try using `10px` for now and see how it looks. If it doesn't match the design you're aiming for, feel free to adjust it! What do you think would work best for your layout?

To determine the appropriate values for the `border` and `border-bottom` properties in your input field, consider the design and style you want to achieve. Here are some common practices:

1. **Border**: This property defines the style, width, and color of the border around the input. A typical value might look like this:
   ```css
   border: 1px solid gray; /* 1 pixel wide, solid line, gray color */
   ```

2. **Border-Bottom**: This property specifically targets the bottom border of the input. You might want to keep it consistent with the overall border or make it different for emphasis. For example:
   ```css
   border-bottom: 2px solid darkslategray; /* 2 pixels wide, solid line, dark slate gray color */
   ```

Putting it all together, your CSS for the input class might look like this:
```css
.input {
    border: 1px solid gray; /* General border */
    border-bottom: 2px solid darkslategray; /* Emphasized bottom border */
}
```

Feel free to adjust the colors and widths based on your design preferences. What do you think would work best for your postcard?

To check your code in a browser, follow these steps:

1. **Open Your Project Folder**: Navigate to the folder where your project files are located. This should include your `index.html` and `styles.css` files.

2. **Open the HTML File**: Locate the `index.html` file. You can do this by right-clicking on the file and selecting "Open with" and then choosing your preferred web browser (like Chrome, Firefox, or Edge).

3. **View in Browser**: Once you open the `index.html` file in the browser, you should see your postcard rendered as per your HTML and CSS code.

4. **Refresh as Needed**: If you make any changes to your HTML or CSS files, save those changes and refresh the browser page (usually by pressing `F5` or clicking the refresh button) to see the updates.

5. **Inspect Elements**: If you want to see how your elements are styled or to debug any issues, you can right-click on the page and select "Inspect" or "Inspect Element." This will open the developer tools where you can see the HTML structure and CSS styles applied.
